project_descr: The Transiition Recovery Programme is a multi-donor funded, multi-project programme focusing on early recovery and subsequently transition to medium and lonter term recovery in the conflict-affected North and East of Sri Lanka.

outputs.output_descr: Cost-effective delivery and management of Transition Recovery Programme
Social cohesion promoted and socio-economically vulnerable groups empowered in 12 conflict-affected DS Divisions in 5 districts of Sri Lanka.

People in target communities in the North and East of Sri Lanka trained on business planning and enterprise development skills, and  Community Based Organizations (CBOs) / institutions receive seed capital to initiate revolving loan among community members for income generating activities

The project aims at facilitating the socio-economic recovery of conflict affected communitites in order to sustain their return and resettlement processes. The social transformation component of the project will attempt to build the capacity of communities for conflict mitigation, dispute resolution and community-based disaster risk reduction; establish community networks as a mechanism to promote social cohesion and gender empowerment; and address a key cause of the conflict through the provision of socio-economic opportunities. 
The following are the six outputs of the Project: 
1. Sustainable livelihood opportunities created for crisis affected communities
2. Micro-credit and Micro Enterprise Development support provided to vulnerable communities and individuals with limited access to credit.
3. Community focused housing provided to crisis affected communities.
4. Access of crisis affected communities to socio-economic services enhanced through rehabilitation of community infrastructure.
5. Enhanced social cohesion and gender empowerment across and within communities in crisis affected areas.
6. Community environmental management mainstreamed into the recovery process of crisis affected communities

The project aims to facilitate the socio-economic recovery of conflict affected communities in order to sustain the return and resettlement processes. The social transformation component of the project will attempt to build the capacity of communities for conflict mitigation, dispute resolution and community-based disaster risk reduction; establish community networks as a mechanism to promote social cohesion and gender empowerment; and address a key cause of the conflict through the provision of socio-economic opportunities. 
The following are the six outputs of the Project: 
(1) Sustainable livelihood opportunities created for crisis affected communities; (2) Micro-credit and micro enterprise development support provided to vulnerable communities and individuals with limited access to credit; (3) Community focused housing provided to crisis affected communities; (4) Access of crisis affected communities to socio-economic services enhanced through rehabilitation of community infrastructure; (5) Enhanced social cohesion and gender empowerment across and within communities in crisis affected areas; (6) Community environmental management mainstreamed into the recovery process of crisis affected communities.

The overall objective of the CRP is to support the socio-economic recovery of IDPs, resettled and host communities in conflict-affected areas in the North and East, through the construction/rehabilitation of critical infrastructure and development of livelihoods.  
Firstly, the action aims to improve access to socio-economic assets, services and facilities and increase opportunities community interaction for target communities through the construction/rehabilitation of community infrastructure.  
Secondly, the action aims to increase opportunities for sustainable livelihood opportunities for target communities through comprehensive capacity building, specifically, through the provision of tools, equipment, inputs, skills training and institutional support to service-providers.

The overall strategy of the project is to provide a comprehensive package of socio-economic recovery support to the targeted communities, while at the same time strengthening their capacities to become self-reliant, and facilitating opportunities for relationship-building among them. 
Followings are the four outputs of the Project:
1. Sustainable livelihood opportunities created for crisis affected communities
2. Community focused housing provided to crisis affected communities.
3. Access of crisis affected communities to socio-economic services enhanced through rehabilitation of community infrastructure.
4. Enhanced social cohesion and gender empowerment across and within communities in crisis affected areas.

The project supports the enhancement of social transformation as part of TRP's community and area-based development approach in support of the resettlement and reintegration of IDPs, returnees and host communities in the North and East of Sri Lanka. The project aims to strengthen the social transformation and social cohesion outputs of the TRP, including its mainstreaming into other donor-funded projects and capacity-development of TRP staff and partners.

Followings are the outputs of the Project.

(1) Sustainable livelihood opportunities created for crisis affected communities; (2) Micro-credit and micro enterprise development support provided to vulnerable communities and individuals with limited access to credit; (3) Community focused housing provided to crisis affected communities; (4) Access of crisis affected communities to socio-economic services enhanced through rehabilitation of community infrastructure; (5) Enhanced social cohesion and gender empowerment across and within communities in crisis affected areas; (6) Community environmental management mainstreamed into the recovery process of crisis affected communities

Sustainable resettlement of returnees in the recently resettled villages of the Mullaitivu and Kilinochchi districts and reducing tensions within and between the target villages by improving their overall socio-economic conditions through construction and renovation of critical community infrastructure, provision of livelihood support, support to micro-credit and micro-enterprise development, as well as strengthening of community structures.

1. Improved social conditions and livelihoods of conflict-affected persons through vocational training and livelihood inputs such as cattle, poultry, seeds, fertilizer, barbed wire, fishing nets, and vallams (traditional boats).
2. Enabling environment created for social transformation and peace building targeting youth through sports in conflict-prone villages while strengthening institutions and decision-making bodies at the community and district levels.

subnational.name: Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka
